reviewText: Not a great film on any level as it was made before history was in the making Overall though, it captures the drama that merchant crews were exposed to early in the war in the Atlantic, having little in the way of self defense and yet fighting an enemy that was at his peak of effectiveness.  It took major guts to serve in a merchantman in the first half of WWII, you couldn't fight back much and you never knew, day or night when disaster was going to strike from U-boats or even German planes in some circumstances.
summary: Not a classic film but still relevant as history
Title: N/A

reviewText: Fans of Bogart or war movies will definitely want to see this one. IMHO one of the best WWII movies made. Along with "Casablanca", "African Queen", "Caine Mutiny", and "Sahara", this was one of the all time great war movies that Bogart created a believeable character you enjoyed watching. The support cast round out the movie and add the the subplots that are needed to give an in depth look at the Merchant Marine. To few movies show groups of people, like the Merchant Marine, that were a large part of why we won wars. I salute them since they don't receive the recognition they deserve. We are quick to erect statues of fighting heroes, but not so quick to honor those that fought by supporting the troops with supplies, construction, first aid, and much more. If you enjoy this be sure catch John Wayne in "The Fighting Seabees". It amazes me that the rights owners of this wonderful movie have not put it on DVD. This will certainly sell as well as any classic John Wayne movie. I always wonder why so much junk is on DVD, but excellent movies like this are only on VHS or out of print (OOP). I love WWII movies and you need a variety to truly appreciate what happened. Movies like "Mrs. Miniver", "Three Came Home" and "Go for Broke" are not mainstream for everyone, but like this movie they give a better idea of the real people that made up not only our fighting forces but the civilian war effort as well. God bless the Merchant Marine. I know what you did has never been fully appreciated. I think movies like this help to make people get a glimmer of what really happened and how we all owe a debt to the Merchant Marines.

reviewText: I love this movie.  My father was skipper of an old freighter and later a Victory Ship during the War, and I see him in the gruff, tough, and yet caring, characters of this film.  He too made the harrowing voyages to  Murmansk and Arkhangelsk, risking the wolfpacks of Uboats and the  divebombers, to deliver supplies to our allies. The US Merchant Marine and  US Naval Armed Guard suffered, percentage-wise, more casualties than any  other service -- but their contribution and sacrifice is rarely told.  "Action in the North Atlantic" depicts the harsh conditions and  danger of the North Atlantic convoys with the level of realism available in  films of its day. It accurately depicts the massive losses of men, ships,  and cargo, and the unconcern of the American public who would neither  refrain from discussing ship movements nor extinguish their city lights to  avoid illuminating departing ships. Yet sailors and gunners were not  detered.  "Action in the North Atlantic" is frequently credited  by veterans as the inspiration of their volunteering.  Those who appreciate  this movie will also enjoy reading "The Captain" by Jan De  Hartog.

reviewText: "Action in the North Atlantic" is a black and white 1943 war film about the merchant marine service.  It stars Humphrey Bogart and Raymond Massey and was directed by Lloyd Bacon.The Merchant Marine is a fleet of civilian owned vessels, formed as early as 1775. In World War 2, the Merchant Marines suffered the highest casualty rates of any service (nearly 4% died), lost 733 ships and 3.1 million tons of cargo. The film follows a group of mariners as they go on two voyages hunted by German submarines.Raymond Massey (1896-1983) is the Captain. Massey is best remembered for his roles as Lincoln - "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" (1940), "The Day Lincoln was Shot" (1950) and  "How the West Was Won" (1962). On TV he played Dr. Gillespie in the series "Dr. Kildare" (1961-5). He made nearly 100 films. I remember him best for his over the top portrayal of John Brown in "Santa Fe Trail" (1940).The crew consists of Alan Hale, Sam Levene, Dane Clark, and Peter Whitney.Dane Clark (1912-98) made dozens of war films but he's probably best known for playing Abe Saperstein in "Go Man Go" (1954).Sam Levene (1905-80) was a staple in film noir and gangster films. He appeared in "Crossfire" (1947), several "Thin Man" films, "The Killers" (1946),  and "Brute Force" (1947)Peter Whitney (1916-72) stood 6'3 and weighed more than 200 pounds, making him an imposing figure in nearly 200 films and TV programs. He's best identified by his bushy eyebrows and his round face.Alan Hale Sr. (1892-1950) is best known as the frequent sidekick to Errol Flynn in films such as "Robin Hood" (1938), "Dodge City" (1939), "Virginia City" (1940), "The Sea Hawk" (1940), "Santa fe Trail" (1940), and "Gentleman Jim" (1942).Lloyd Bacon (1889-1955) directs. Bacon directed more than 100 films between 1922 and 1954, the most famous of which are "42nd Street" (1933), "A Slight Case of Murder" (1938), "Brother Orchid" (1940), and "Footsteps in the Dark" (1941). He was typically known for any style, but as a working director who could make a film within budget and time constraints.The film received an Oscar nomination for Best Original Screenplay. The writer John Howard Lawson (1894-1977), specialized in war films, especially involving the Navy, and was nominated for his first Oscar for "Blockade" (1938). He was a founder of the Writer's Guild and served as an ambulance driver in France in World War 1. But with the red scare in the late 40s, Lawson was identified as a communist and his career ended.FWIW - Director Lloyd Bacon and star Humphrey Bogart both served in the Navy during World War 1. Raymond Massey fought in France with the Canadian Field Artillery. Writer John Howard Lawson was an ambulance driver in France. Producer Jerry Wald finished working on this film then enlisted.1943 was an OK year in films - The top grossing films included "This is the Army", "For Whom the Bell Tolls", "Song of Bernadette", "Coney Island", and "Stage Door Canteen". Other notables included "The Ox Bow Incident". The big Oscar winner was "Going My Way", and other winners included "Gaslight" and "None But the Lonely Heart"War films were particularly popular - "Air Force" with John Garfield, "Bataan" with Robert Taylor and Lloyd Nolan, "Bombadier" with Pat O'Brien and Randolph Scott, "Corvette K-255" with Randolph Scott, "Five Graves to Cairo" with Franchet Tone and Anne Baxter, "Hangmen Also Die" with Brian Donlevy and Walter Brennan, and "Hitler's Children."The film has some good action sequences, especially the sinking of one of the ships and a battle between a ship and 2 German planes. The naval scenes, though, are obviously done in a tank and the models are not very convincing, even for 1943.Nonetheless it's really good to see a film about the Merchant Marines, heroes who typically don't get a lot of attention. There are only a few such films (e.g., "Mister Roberts", "The Wreck of the Mary Deare").

reviewText: Much of Allied success in the Second World War depended on the delivery by sea of American munitions, tanks, and planes to our allies in Great Britain and Russia.  The men of the U.S. Merchant Marine manned the liberty ships that delivered the goods against tremendous odds in the form of German submarine and aircraft attack.  1943's "Action in the North Atlantic", filmed while that battle was still in progress, is a tribute to their courage."Action in the North Atlantic" follows the crew of a liberty ship in their journey across the North Atlantic and then across the North Sea, bound for the port of Murmansk in Soviet Russia.  Raymond Massy is the stalwart ship's captain, Humphrey Bogart his sympathetic lieutenent, and Alan Hale the rowdy but effective bosun's mate.  The crew is the obligatory cross section of humanity, including a ship's engineer with a broad Scottish accent, a sailor whose feet hurt when a submarine is around, and an augmentation of young Navy gunners who help defend the ship.The ship survives a hair-raising crossing of the North Atlantic, as German submarines repeatedly challenge its convoy.  One German submarine in particular makes the war personal, pursuing the liberty ship into the North Sea.  The climax of the movie is a suspensful cat-and-mouse duel to the death between Bogart, now acting ship's captain, and the wily German submarine captain.  A mass burial at sea provides Bogart the opportunity to put into appropriate words the credo and patriotism of his merchant mariners.For a wartime effort, the movie is remarkably even-handed.  The German submariners are portrayed as the tough and competent fighters they were.  The movie finds time to pay homage to the regular Navy and the Army Air Corps for their parts in the Battle of the North Atlantic.  The special efforts pale in comparison to today's CGI, but were state of the art for the time.  Real footage is intercut with the simulations to add to the effect of ships racing around the ocean.This movie is very highly recommended as a suspenseful war movie and as an exemplar of its wartime genre.

reviewText: This great sea tale staring Humphrey Bogart and Raymond Massey is a good patriotic homage to the World War II sailors of the maritime service. Dane Clark as seamen Johnny Pulaski is a standout. Clark's acting deserved more recognition than he ever got. Alan Hale is also on board. Lloyd Bacon's direction is somewhat pedestrian but Producer Jerry Wald's fine production values, good action sequences and Adolph Deutsch's score compensate a lot.
summary: Recognition to the Men of the Maritime Service

On the other hand, What else could it be done at that decisive year?A fine cast and a dazzling set of special effects for those Ages make of this movie a sensible but sincere homage in memory of so many bold and brave men who died for a better world.Fine direction of Lloyd Bacon.

reviewText: "Action in the North Atlantic" is a timeless story of the courage and heroism of the men who served in the Merchant Marine and the armed guard that supplied our fighting men with the essential provisions required to conduct the war while recording one of its highest casualty rates. A bit overdone at times but Bogart and Massey give exemplary performances. A propaganda film of the first order that manages to show the scope of the war and the importance the Merchant Marine Service. Special effects are hokey by todays standards but the crew is populated by a good supporting cast including Alan Hale, Dane Clark and Julie Bishop. A look at World War II from a different perspective. Worth watching.

reviewText: Humprhey Bogart is part of a great ensemble cast in this WWII film that demonstrates the important contribution of the merchant marines.  Bogart  and Raymond Massey are solid as officers on board the ship, both committed  to their careers and country, and both eager to return to the women they  have left at home (Julie Bishop and Ruth Gordon).  Among others on board is  the always likeable Alan Hale, as well as Dane Clark, who gives a good  performance as an intense sailor questioning his commitment to the cause.  Lloyd Bacon doesn't direct with much style, but he punches across all the  action scenes and keeps the film moving.  Watching this film, I developed a  greater respect and knowledge for the role the merchant marines played  during WWII.

reviewText: Most people today don't reliaze the great number of Merchant Marines that lost their lives during WWII as so wecould today have our freedom. There were more Merchant Seamen killed (in comparison to the number each service branch had) then any of the other armed forces. A gun on the stem and the stern can't do a lot against a German Sub! A real salute to Warner Brothers for making a movie that really lets a naive person see what it was like. Everything from the USMM enlisting posters hanging in the tavern to shipboard words like "how about that night-lunch"in this movie is presented true. For men like myself who take pride in the time we sailed the vast oceans of the world as part of our Merchant Marine this movie really can make us proud !  note: Raymond Massey was outstanding as the Old Man, He reminded me of a Captain Brown that I sailed under some 30+ years ago.This movie is even better then the 5 star rating ,it is a real piece of American Maritime History!  "ENJOY"
summary: Learning the Truth of the US Merchant Marine in WWII

reviewText: Warner Bros. Pictures presents "ACTION IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC" (1943) (129 min/B&W;) -- Starring Humphrey Bogart, Raymond Massey, Alan Hale, Julie Bishop, Ruth Gordon & Dane ClarkDirected by Lloyd BaconThis film boasts of a splendid cast and spectacular cinematography.  Lloyd Bacon directs with a firm, vigorous treatment of all the battle scenes and only occasionally does the film slow down when dealing with the domestic front. Julie Bishop does a nice job as Bogart's girlfriend and later wife, while Raymond Massey shares his domestic homecoming with Ruth Gordon as his wife. But the film's merits are chiefly due to the action sequences, which are by far among the best ever featured in a Bogart film.Dane Clark plays his usual hothead role with gusto and Alan Hale is a welcome addition to the supporting cast.Bogart is given some flag-waving lines to read and the film concludes with a commentary using FDR's voice to salute the Merchant Marines and their contribution to the war effort.The film has a great black and white photography by Ted McCord and a haunting musical score by Adolph Deutsch. The battle scenes were staged by Lloyd Bacon with an uncredited assistance from Raoul Walsh and they are amazing for what was accomplished in those days where the technology wasn't so advanced.A great action WWII film with Bogie at his peak with enjoyable support from Massey - Oscar nominated for Best Writing, Original Story.BIOS:1. Lloyd Bacon [aka: Lloyd Francis Bacon]Date of Birth: 4 December 1889 - San Jose, CaliforniaDate of Death: 15 November 1955 - Burbank, California2. Humphrey BogartDate of Birth: 25 December 1899 - New York City, New YorkDate of Death: 14 January 1957 - Los Angeles, California3. Pictures ~ (03/07/2000)

reviewText: WWII action adventure, enjoyable for "old fashioned Hollywood" imagination.  I rate this only 3 stars as it is not a first-rate "Bogie" picture,  was a propaganda film for the war effort, and the U-boat propaganda is exaggerated and not historically valid; this is a slight flaw for my enjoyment as I am an amateur historian and specialize in submarine history.  A nice selection of co-stars from Warner's character stable, including Alan Hale and at least two others who had also appeared in Warner's "Destination Tokyo," one of my Warner's WWII favorites.

reviewText: By the time that ACTION IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC was released in 1943, Hollywood had been fully invested in raising morale for a war that was far from being won.  Most of the big budget war films of the time focused tightly on the major armed services.  AINA dealt with the far less known exploits of the Merchant Marines.  Director Lloyd Bacon showed a microcosm of war that was the cold waters of the North Atlantic.  This vast area of ocean was a vital cog in keeping the supply lines open between the factories of the United States and the Allied powers that so desperately needed them.  The actors for the most part were well known and the audience had an immediate connection.  Raymond Massey was the captain of a freighter that was transporting war supplies to our then ally the Russians in Murmansk.  Massey plays the captain as the rock of respectability that was his essential screen persona.  Humphrey Bogart was his executive officer whose own gruff manner well pairs off against Massey's avuncular style.  Then there is a host of lesser lights led by Alan Hale, a man whose low brow humor blends seamlessly into the maelstrom that was marine combat.The plot involves an American Liberty sea freighter running the gauntlet of Nazi submarines trying to choke off the nearly infinite flow of supplies from America.  There is one German submarine whose captain plays a cat and mouse game that would set the standard for future ship versus ship war epics (remember the STAR TREK episode where Kirk engages in a similar battle against a Romulan commander?). Here, Massey and the German captain try all the tricks to force the other into a fatal and premature move. The battle scenes are clearly miniaturized ships in a big tub but nevertheless engrossing for that.  There is never any doubt about the "rightness" of the Allied cause nor does the film try to undermine public morale by implying that somehow we were the cause of hostilities. What emerges by the final reel is the quaint but reassuring feeling that when war is truly necessary, Hollywood can step in with the confidence that America was and is in the right.
summary: The "Good War" of the North Atlantic

reviewText: i watched Destination Tokyo, and as soon as it was over, started watching this. Destination Tokyo is a tough act for this movie to follow. by comparison, Action in the North Atlantic gets off to a very slow start; somehow, even 18 minutes in, after our heroes' ship has been torpedoed several times, is burning brightly, and all the crew members' lives are in direct peril, i still find myself bored and waiting for something unpredictable to happen.18:20 is as far as i've gotten, and probably as far as i will get.this may be a great movie, seen on its own. all i know is that, seen as a follow-up to Destination Tokyo, *i* find it boar-*ring.*

reviewText: There weren't a great deal of movies about the auxillary outfits that aided the war effort abroad in WWII.  John Wayne's "The Fighting Seabees" comes to mind as well as a Martha Raye USO picture or two.  However, "Action in the North Atlantic" qualifies as sort of the epic picture of the limited genre.  It's about the Merchant Marines and it stars Humphrey Bogart in a somewhat subdued yet very effective role.  There's a fair amount of naval action as well as a lot of shipmate camaradarie, and even a romantic interlude (don't worry, it's not on the ship).  We get a sense that these men are preforming a vital task at a high risk to themselves.Besides Bogart, there is an interesting array of actors with Alan Hale and Raymond Massey as the other two names that might be recognized.  The actors portray a diverse group of individuals who know their jobs and believe in what they're doing.  There's one scene in particular where Bogart officiates (substituting for the wounded captain) at a funeral at sea service.  There is a strong homily that he delevers that seems to be the high point of the movie.  It is well done and forceful in the Bogart way."Action in the North Atlantic" may seem a bit long but it had a story to tell to a nation that needed to hear it and at a time it needed to be said.  So what if it took an extra 20 minutes in doing so.
summary: Appropriate Tribute to a Deserving Group

reviewText: They didn't sail powerful destroyers or fill the skies with waves of carrier-borne fighters, but the men of the US Merchant Marine nevertheless fought and won the second world war's most crucial and consistently bloody battles - the Battle of the Atlantic. This excellent film follows the travails of a merchantman bound for Russia's arctic port of Murmansk with a cargo of materials the Russians need to keep the Germans pegged on the eastern front. Through the war, American convoys sailed mass-built "Liberty Ships" through waters teeming with German planes, cruisers and U-Boats to keep both England and Russia properly equipped. While tides of war may have shifted thruought the war, allied convoys faced constant attacks by axis units until the end, relying mainly on their ability to absorb severe casualties.This film is fiction and, produced during the war (1943) has the hallmarks of a propaganda film. But "Action" is so much more - with winning performances by Humphrey Bogart and Ray Massey, and a fine supporting crew that sounds like they may have actually sailed the dreaded "Murmansk Run". The special effects are astoundingly good for 1943 and hold up pretty well today. The Germans are perfect as skilled hunters - I still get a chill during the battle scenes when whole crews utter "torpedo - los!" - not quite dehumanized, but still fearsome. Crisp direction makes their untranslated lines the best case against sub-titles. This flick easily surpasses similar movies like "Air Force" in capturing the warime fervor while serving up a great story.  In short, a great film.
summary: Wartime classic - Bogart, Massey & crew deliver the goods!
